article_title: A father and son's long journey turns to grief
article_text:
A father and son's long journey turns to grief Houstonian couldn't get affordable treatment in time to save his paranoid schizophrenic son

article_metadata.description: A father's desperate fight turns to grief  When the police called that March day in 2008 to say they arrested his son, another piece of James McSwain's heart broke.  In his deeply troubled mind the driver was trying to steal his father's car, which was the same make and model.  Authorities had always treated Phillip gently, understanding  he was mentally ill, McSwain says.  [...] instead I talked to a friend of mine who is prominent criminal defense attorney and he agreed to help.  The jail treats more psychiatric patients than all of Texas' state-run public mental hospitals combined.  Even if he could find a bed in Houston's dwindling supply of inpatient psychiatric facilities, Phillip would be released long before he was ready.  Looking back, though, he saw signs of trouble when Phillip was still in high school.  Doctors said his son needed long-term, structured cognitive therapy much like a stroke patient would receive.  Payment was due in advance: $60,000 for two months of treatment, and while the psychiatric facility took insurance, no insurer would cover the care.  [...] McSwain pieced together the best treatment he could find for his son, often paying for it out of pocket: I burned through every credit card I had.  On Feb. 9, 2009, around 7  p.m., McSwain was at dinner with friends when a wave of fear passed over him.  [...] the longest period of treatment Phillip ever got was 2½ months.
article_metadata.author.name: By Jenny Deam
